data.text: Garmin GPS or Should I Just Use a Phone for Navigation?

I’m debating on splurging on a nice Garmin GPS, or could I get by with just using my phone in Bike mode temporarily? I know that a dedicated bike gps will overall be better, but $400 is a nice chunk to drop!
Get an eTrex. You can get a 30x for about $150 refurbished. It doesn't have a touch screen which is an advantage in my book and has a long battery life on 2 AA batteries.
data.author: Gus Laskaris

data.text: Get a Wahoo it's cheaper. You should have a separate GPS in case you crash you don't want to break your phone
data.author: Steve Cardin

data.text: Never thought of that, you might have just convinced me to get one.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: Yeap, a new phone is $800. I like the eTrex 30…
data.author: Rafael Melanda

data.text: plus if you have an emergency you need your phone. Better to have it in a bag tucked away somewhere.
data.author: Steve Cardin

data.text:
My phones have survived several singletrack OTBs when installed to bars with a Finn elastic thingy, getfinn.com
Homepage
getfinn.com
data.author: Matti Koukkula

data.text: Phone works quite well with strava.
data.author: David Baker-Yuill

data.text: Garmin edge 130 is only $250 Gets the job done well
data.author: George Eglesfield

data.text: I paid a lot less than 400$ for my wahoo.
data.author: Douglas Miner

data.text: I enjoy an eTrex. Simple, affordable, long battery life and perfect for BikePacking
data.author: Wes Mendenhall

data.text: yup
data.author: Ray Egan

data.text: I think phone would be fine - the downside is the battery life. Battery life will be better in airplane mode.
data.author: Leif Warner

data.text: can get a big back up battery
data.author: Theann Faucher

data.text: +1 for the wahoo. Either way having a dedicated bicycle computer is quite preferable to using the phone
data.author: Dave Cohen

data.text: Gaia on my phone (premium so I can use offline) and Zoleo to keep it touch with my family when I'm out for several weeks at a time. Also has an SOS button.
data.author: Louie J. Frucci

data.text: Gaia is great. yeah you gotta figure out the charging
data.author: Erik Rowberg

data.text: Absolutely a problem. I carry a few small battery packs and also look for plugs in campgrounds or towns I pass through.
data.author: Louie J. Frucci

data.text:
I got my Garmin Edge 810 in 2013 because just tracking my rides was killing my phone battery. Garmin’s still going but phone has been replaced twice. I used the reviews on dcrainmaker.com to choose which cycle computer to buy. At the time, only the 810 offered the navigation features I wanted.
DC Rainmaker
dcrainmaker.com
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: What do you need? Turn by turn directions, occasional map guidance, just tracking your rides? A smartphone can do all these things but not quite as efficiently as a dedicated bike GPS.
data.author: J.c. Mcguirk

data.text: I got a Stages m50 for $150. It’s fantastic
data.author: James Folsom

data.text: Get a used garmin 520+ got mine for 120. Works great! 520+ is the cheapest model with navigation. Phone is fine unless you're going on really long rides with no battery backup, but a bc is nice to have. I got mine when I got a power meter.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: Pick up one of these, I’ve had mine for over a year with no issues
data.author: Shrewz Bury

data.text:
https://youtu.be/3qlrqh5Yahc
Bryton RIder 750 Review - $270 Dollar Cycling GPS Unit w/ Voice Navigation
youtube.com
data.author: Shrewz Bury

data.text: Etrex all the way, simple, AA batteries , and bombproof 💪
data.author: Martin Kubes

data.text: It depends on what you do. For overnight trips mostly on road, a phone is fine. MTB trails might be a bit risky as phone can get dust, mud, or be hit by a tree or something. Anything longer than 3 days I'd want a separate device, if only to serve as a backup at minimum, but it also uses less battery life, and is more rugged. If I were to choose again, I'd get the Karoo Hammerhead 2.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: I've been using my Garmin 810 for the last couple of years, can't fault it......
data.author: Mark Randlesome

data.text: iCardio app on iPhone with a $15 cadence sensor and an Apple Watch has been awesome for me. It’s accurate and it’s easy and has all the functions that you’d want with the garmin.
data.author: P.W. Poubelle

data.text: I was using a hiking GPS for a while but the colour screen with all the extra roads & trails displayed were a bit "busy" to glance at while riding. Eventually got a Garmin Edge 130+ which has a simple monochrome screen and only shows your route (no other trails/roads cluttering up the screen). Also displays turn-by-turn notifications/advance warnings
data.author: Gareth Barker

data.text: Etrex 30x, works perfectly and extremely affordable!
data.author: Danny Hill

data.text:
Problem solved: Garmin eTrex 32x, Rugged Handheld GPS Navigator https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07RR6GZWP/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_glt_i_JT5TXYWSZ70VX9M3DWZ4
Garmin eTrex 32x, Rugged Handheld GPS Navigator
amazon.com
data.author: James Wilson

data.text: Cellphone only works with cell reception. 🥴
data.author: Dave Becker-Ellison

data.text: Depends on what app you are running. Most good navigation apps allow you to download the maps to your phone and the gps signal is all you need. You can then leave the phone in “airplane” mode to save battery.
data.author: Grahame Joy

data.text: Get a Garmin or Wahoo, approx. 250 bucks and they will do everything you want/need from such a device.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: I’ve got a nice GPS but, in retrospect, useing my handle bar mounted phone with an auxiliary battery and ridewithgps app would probably serve me equally.
data.author: Kent Redmond

data.text: Phone is fine until you drop the bike or worse case crash and you destroy your only navigation and your only form of communication. Garmin Etrex is a great price with much better battery life than your phone. Tuck that phone somewhere safe as backup.
data.author: Andy Lovell

data.text: I use an old phone. No sim. Put in flight mode, disabled all apps except maps. Battery lasts ages. Worked for years
data.author: Geoff Currie

data.text: Wahoo Roam
data.author: Peter Cartier

data.text: I've got a Bryton rider 420 which I like a lot. Very long battery life. Much better recording abilities than a phone. I tend to use manual maps on my phone for navigating.
data.author: Tom Stickland

data.text: I got a garmin, but I am not sure I would buy one now. Phones have much bigger screens and are nicer to look at. The only reason for buying a Garmin was battery life. I plan to make a bike packing trip in the summer and my gf bought me a battery with solar panel, which is enough to keep the phone alive. You can mount your phone on the bars and put the solar battery in one of those bike phone bags.
data.author: Dinu Nicolae

data.text: Bought a Garmin 1030 a couple of years back & it’s been one of the best purchases I’ve ever made! The battery life is brilliant, it’s helped me find a lot of amazing places & it’s also helped me navigate in areas without a phone signal
data.author: Ashley Burton

data.text: They are great at tracking, not so great at navigation, but it eats much more less electricity then a phone. Btw it is not a necessity, some would say you do not really NEED to track all of your activities. (Bullshit, you definitely need one :D )
data.author: Ványi Dániel Attila

data.text: As they say, " you can't take it with you" spend the money, that's what it's for.
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: IMO carrying two phones or a phone and a GPS just adds extra weight. I use my iphone X on airplane mode with Gaia maps and mount it with a quadlock.
data.author: Todd McMurray
